===Etymology 2===
{{root|en|ine-pro|*gʷem-}}
Variant of {{m|en|come}}, attested (in the basic sense "come, move from further to nearer, arrive") since Old English. The sexual sense of ''come'' is attested since the 1650s. In this sense and spelling, attested from 1970s.<ref>{{R:Etymonline|cum}}</ref>

=====Usage notes=====
Many style guides and editors recommend the spelling ''[[come]]'' for verb uses (''to orgasm''/''to ejaculate'') while strictly allowing the spelling ''cum'' for the noun (''semen''/''female ejaculatory discharge''). Both spellings are sometimes found in either the noun or verb sense, however. Others prefer to distinguish in formality, using ''come'' for any formal usage and ''cum'' only in slang, erotic or pornographic contexts.<ref>[http://www.glossophilia.org/?p=4925 Glossophilia]</ref>

The past tense and past participle variant ''cummed'' is used when the verb is felt as a denominal from the noun rather than a specialized sense of the verb ''come''.

===Etymology 2===
From {{inh|la|itc-ola|quom}}, from {{der|la|ine-pro|*kʷóm}}, accusative of {{m|ine-pro|*kʷos}}, {{m|ine-pro|*kʷis}}. Compare its feminine form {{m|la|quam}} (as in {{m|la|tum}}-{{m|la|tam}}).

====Alternative forms====
* {{alt|la|quom||acl|classical}}
* {{alt|la|quum||pcl}}

====Conjunction====
{{head|la|conjunction}}

# {{+obj|la|sub}} 
## {{lb|la|causal}} [[when]], [[after]] {{+obj|la|impf&subj/plup&subj}} 
## [[because]], [[since]]
## [[although]]
# {{+obj|la|ind}} 
## {{lb|la|temporal}} when, [[while]] {{+obj|la|pres&ind/perf&ind}} 

=====Usage notes=====
* In the sense of [[when]], if there is no causal link between the verb in the dependent clause and the verb in the main clause (sometimes called an inverted {{m|la||cum}}-clause, as the 'main action' of the sentence occurs in the dependent clause), the indicative is used rather than the subjunctive.
*: {{m|la||Per viam ambulābāmus '''cum''' pugnam vīdimus.}} [not {{m|la||*vīderīmus}}]
*::We were walking through the street '''when''' we saw a fight.
* Often coupled with {{m|la|tum}}, such that {{m|la||tum X, cum Y}} means "then X, when Y", and {{m|la||cum X tum Y}} means "not only X but also Y".
*: {{Q|la|Titus Livius|Ab Urbe Condita|I|13|quote={{l|la|movet}} {{l|la|res}} '''cum''' {{l|la|multitudinem}} '''tum''' {{l|la|duces}}|t=This event '''not only''' shocked the crowd '''but also''' the commanders}}
